unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**

unnormalised: New Delhi, Oct 26 – Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL) announced a significant expansion of its Fiber-to-the-Home (FTTH) network across tier-II cities, aiming to connect an additional 50,000 homes in the next quarter. The initiative, spearheaded by Dr. Rajesh Kumar, aims to provide high-speed internet access, crucial for online education and e-governance initiatives in rural areas like Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.
normalised: New Delhi, october twenty six – Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (B S N L) announced a significant expansion of its Fiber-to-the-Home (F T T H) network across tier-two cities, aiming to connect an additional fifty thousand homes in the next quarter. The initiative, spearheaded by Doctor Rajesh Kumar, aims to provide high-speed internet access, crucial for online education and e-governance initiatives in rural areas like Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.

unnormalised: Reliance Jio also unveiled plans to cover another 100 km of fiber optic cable, focusing on densely populated areas in Mumbai and Chennai. Experts estimate the investment at Rs. 500 Crores. The increased bandwidth will support burgeoning data consumption, driven by streaming services and online businesses. Concerns remain, however, regarding laying infrastructure in congested urban areas, requiring permissions and managing right-of-way. Local residents, like Mrs. Sharma of Andheri, hope that better connectivity will facilitate remote work, providing much-needed respite from daily commutes and enhancing digital literacy in her 800 sq ft apartment.
normalised: Reliance Jio also unveiled plans to cover another one hundred kilometer of fiber optic cable, focusing on densely populated areas in Mumbai and Chennai. Experts estimate the investment at rupee five hundred crores. The increased bandwidth will support burgeoning data consumption, driven by streaming services and online businesses. Concerns remain, however, regarding laying infrastructure in congested urban areas, requiring permissions and managing right-of-way. Local residents, like Missus Sharma of Andheri, hope that better connectivity will facilitate remote work, providing much-needed respite from daily commutes and enhancing digital literacy in her eight hundred square feet apartment.
